about_paragraph_1: CS2 is a player-driven cheat jurisdiction process initially modeled after the Overwatch system in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, but now applied outside the game environment. This system works alongside traditional security measures and enlists experienced and trustworthy application users, designated as Investigators, who review usage logs and data contexts with suspected unauthorized activities.
about_paragraph_2: Investigators assess the information to determine whether the user in question has engaged in cheating or has compromised the application's integrity. A verdict of "guilty" leads to consequences such as access bans or restrictions imposed on the offender's account.
about_paragraph_3: To participate as an Investigator in CS2, users must have a proven activity record and cannot have their involvement obscured by inactivity. If an Investigator's participation eligibility lapses due to inactivity, they must re-establish their active status to regain access to the CS2 system. As noted in the update on March 22, 2023, the original Overwatch feature was phased out from Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, and this change was reflected in the application-based adaptation.
name: Name
select_type: Please selecte an evidence type you would like to provide.
placeholder_description: Describe the cheating incident... and why you think it is cheating

review_resolution_content.intro: Now that you've reviewed the evidence, it is your duty to determine the facts for each of the categories below. Note that for each category of disruption you should presume the suspect to be innocent. Only if you are confident that you witnessed behavior that would be agreed upon by the CS:GO community to be disruptive, anti-competitive, and/or anti-social beyond a reasonable doubt should you select Evident Beyond a Reasonable Doubt. If you are not 100% confident in your decision, you should select Insufficient Evidence.
review_resolution_content.postpone: If you don't feel that you were able to dedicate the appropriate attention level required to reach a verdict, please click on Postpone Judgement. The case will remain available for you to review at a later time.

aim_assistance.title: Major Disruption: Aim Assistance
aim_assistance.description: The evidence you reviewed would be judged, by any reasonable member of the CS:GO community, as clearly demonstrating that The Suspect used external software to improve their aim, e.g. automated targeting, recoil reduction or elimination, etc.

vision_assistance.title: Major Disruption: Vision Assistance
vision_assistance.description: The evidence you reviewed would be judged, by any reasonable member of the CS:GO community, as clearly demonstrating that The Suspect used external software to gain information about locations of their opponents, e.g. vision through walls or smoke, flashbang effect reduction or elimination, etc.

external_assistance.title: Major Disruption: Other External Assistance
external_assistance.description: The evidence you reviewed would be judged, by any reasonable member of the CS:GO community, as clearly demonstrating that The Suspect used external software other than those listed above to gain an advantage over their opponents, e.g. speedhacking, automated jumping scripts, upside-down views, etc.

griefing.title: Minor Disruption: Griefing
griefing.description: The evidence you reviewed would be judged, by any reasonable member of the CS:GO community, as clearly demonstrating that The Suspect exhibited behavior that was disruptive, anti-competitive, and/or anti-social, e.g. deliberately interfering with or trying to damage or be damaged by teammates, or deliberately losing the match.
